items.description: Loughborough urban watercourses and local tributaries to the River Soar
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed.

items.description: River Leen, Day Brook and Tottle Brook in Nottinghamshire

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Leen, Day Brook, Tottle Brook

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

River levels are rising at the Whitewater Bridge river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall earlier today.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Mansfield, the Sherwood Forest Caravan Park at Clipstone, Edwinstowe, Ollerton, Whitewater Lane at Whitewater Bridge and West Drayton.   
We expect river levels to remain high the morning on 21/06/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.    
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 08:00, 21/06/23, or as the situation changes.

Small, flashier rivers and streams are beginning to respond to heavy rainfall as a result of localised thunderstorms passing through the area.  
Areas most at risk are low lying agricultural land, roads and footpaths close to small rivers and streams.  Water levels could rise rapidly and potentially generate deep, fast flows.   
We expect river levels to remain high until 21:00 on 20/06/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid contact with flood water and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 20:00 this evening, 20/06/23, or as the situation changes."

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  Further rainfall is possible later in the week. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

This Flood Alert is being removed as there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area. Heavy rainfall has now cleared the area and river levels are now falling. 
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Scrase Bridge and West Common Streams

floodArea.riverOrSea: Scrase Bridge Stream, West Common Stream

items.message: The intense showers of early Tuesday morning (20/06/2023) have now moved away. River levels on the Scrasebridge and West Common Streams have fallen significantly from their peak, are now near normal, and are still falling. The next five days are currently forecast to remain predominantly dry. We do not currently expect further periods of flood risk this week. However, further isolated showers are possible Wednesday and Thursday (22/06/2023). We will continue to monitor the river levels and rainfall forecast, and proactively clear and operate our structures. Please continue to monitor the weather forecast for updates on the potential showers over the coming days, and take precautions with flood resistance and resilience measures if appropriate. We will re-issue this Flood Alert, or a Flood Warning if the risk of flooding becomes possible or expected again.

floodArea.county: Barnet, Enfield, Essex, Greater London, Haringey, Hertfordshire, Redbridge, Waltham Forest
floodArea.riverOrSea: Ching Brook, Cobbins Brook, Nazeing Brook, Pymmes Brook, Salmons Brook, Turkey Brook, Small River Lee, Rags Brook, Trinity Marsh Ditch

items.message:
River levels in the tributaries of the River Lee have fallen since the morning of Tuesday 20 June.
 
The risk of thunderstorms has also now passed and no further flooding to fields and roads is expected in the area, however there may be areas of standing water that will slowly drain away over the next few days.
  
Some lighter rain is possible overnight but is not expected to make river levels rise again.

We will continue to monitor the river level and observe weather forecasts and will issue any new flood message when needed.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Camel, River Allen, Bodmin Town Leat, River Valency

items.message:
Flooding is possible through this afternoon and evening of Tuesday 20th June, due to heavy rain passing through the region. In particular, intense rainfall in the Bodmin area has caused water levels in the Bodmin Town Leat catchment to rise rapidly, however other watercourses within this warning area may also see rising levels. Levels are expected to peak between 4pm and 10pm. Areas primarily at risk include low lying land and roads.

The heaviest rainfall is expected to have cleared the area by around 9pm this evening, however isolated heavy showers remain possible into the early hours, with further possible heavy showers during Wednesday 21st June.  Further response from rivers remains possible

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area ready to respond as required.

This message will be updated Wednesday morning or earlier if the situation changes.
